summary: Consumers today expect goods and services to be hyper-personalized and on demand . Subscription models have further increased usage and stickiness of many online consumer services . The 8 consumer subscription stocks we track reported a satisfactory Q1. As a group, revenues beat analysts’ consensus estimates by 1.9% while next quarter’s revenue guidance was in line .  Netflix reported revenues of $10.54 billion, up 12.5% year on year . Overall, it was a strong quarter for the company with EPS guidance for next quarter exceeding analysts’ expectations . Duolingo (NASDAQ:DUOL) pulled off the fastest revenue growth and highest full-year EBITDA guidance . The stock is up 31% since reporting and currently trades at $1,278 .  Roku (NASDAQ: ROKU) makes hardware players that offer access to various online streaming TV services . Founded by two Stanford University computer science professors, Coursera (NYSE:COUR) is an online learning platform that offers courses, specializations, and degrees from top universities and organizations around the world .  Coursera reported revenues of $179.3 million, up 6.1% year on year . This result beat analysts’ expectations by 2.3%. Overall, it was a strong quarter as it also produced EBITDA guidance for next quarter exceeding analysts' expectations . The stock is up 10.8% since reporting and currently trades at $8.51 .  The stock is flat since reporting and currently trades at $6.85 . As a result of the Fed’s rate hikes in 2022 and 2023, inflation has come down from frothy levels post-pandemic . This, combined with recent rate cuts (half a percent in September 2024 and a quarter percent in November 2024) have led to strong stock market performance in 2024 .  These companies are poised for growth regardless of the political or macroeconomic climate . Want to invest in winners with rock-solid fundamentals?
